I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by Phu Bia Mining Limited, both 
to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector 
Project.1  

The project will improve the performance of provincial water utilities, called provincial nam 
2. 
papas (PNPs), and expand access to safe piped water supply and sanitation for urban residents 
in small towns in the Lao PDR. It will be financed by a sector loan as it meets the criteria in the 
sector  lending  policy  of  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).2 It  will  contribute  to  the  government’s 
urban sector targets—90% coverage for piped water supply and 100% coverage for sanitation by 
2030—by  improving  sector  coordination  and  policy  implementation  in  corporatization,  improving 
nonrevenue  water  (NRW)  management  and  expanding  water  supply  in  provincial  towns, 
developing new water supply systems in small towns, enhancing community action in urban water 
supply  and  sanitation,  and  strengthening  capacity  for  project  implementation  and  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M). The project will expand water and sanitation services to small district towns, 
provincial  capital  towns  and  their  peri-urban  areas  in  accordance  with  the  government’s  urban 
water supply and sanitation strategy, 2013–2030 and water supply investment plan, 2012–2020.3   

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3. 
The project provides financing to corporatized PNPs for the development and expansion 
of  water  supply  systems  and  village  improvements  to  help  reinforce  links  between  sanitation 
and  health.  It  complements  existing  projects  by  further  strengthening  the  performance  of 
corporatized  PNPs  through  innovative  approaches  to  NRW  management,  water  safety  plan 
implementation,  and  O&M  training  through  a  water  operator  partnership.  It  demonstrates  the 
benefits of improved utility performance and efficiency on expanding water supply and sanitation 
services  to  small  district  towns  and  peri-urban  areas  of  provincial  capital  towns.  It  showcases 
ADB  as  a  finance++  bank  through  (i)  its  partnership  with  Phu  Bia  Mining  Limited,  which  will 
provide  project  specific  cofinancing  through  its  sustainability  initiative,  commonly  known  as 
corporate  social  responsibility,  and  (ii)  ADB’s  support  to  the  government  in  strengthening  its 
mechanism for coordinating development partners in the sector through output 1. 

4. 
The Lao PDR population was estimated in 2011 at 6.4 million, of whom a third reside in five 
large urban centers and 150 small towns in 144 districts. Gross domestic product was estimated at 
$1,270  per  capita  in  2011  and  $1,422  in  2012. The poverty rate  declined to  28%  in  2008  and  is 
projected to fall by one percentage point per annum.4 The development of urban centers and small 
towns is important to improve living conditions and public health, strengthen urban–rural linkages, 
generate  employment,  and  narrow  regional  income  disparities.  Increased  access  to  safe  and 
reliable water and sanitation plays a vital role in the economic development of these towns. About 
58% of urban residents had access to piped water supply and 87% to improved sanitation in 2011.

 2           

Urban water supply and sanitation  sector in the Lao PDR used to lack sustainability and 
5. 
effective  sector  regulation.  Transforming  PNPs  into  profit-making  corporatized  business  entities 
was a challenge because of their limited institutional capacity. PNPs operated at a loss because 
of  low  tariffs,  few  water  connections,  and  poor  managerial  and  operational  performance.  This 
resulted in poor PNP technical and financial performance, poor service to consumers, and PNPs’ 
reliance on the government for budget support.5 Since 2008, PNPs have corporatized under the 
Enterprise Law, 2005 and adopted a more business-like approach in line with the government’s 
reforms for state-owned enterprises. The legal framework has improved with the approval of the 
Water Supply Law in 2009, the issuance of an urban water supply and sanitation strategy in 2013, 
and improved national and provincial sector regulation.  

6. 
ADB  has  supported  the  government  improve  its  sector  performance  through  three  loans 
for small towns that have (i) developed and rehabilitated 31 small town water supply systems; (ii) 
applied appropriate technology to the design of water supply systems; (iii) improved construction 
standards  through  technical  support  to  construction  contractors  and  onsite  supervision;  (iv) 
improved  the  operational  and  financial  performance  of  PNPs  through  regular  tariff  adjustments 
and reduced arrears (7 of 16 PNPs have achieved full cost recovery, and 10 reduced arrears to 
less than 90 days in 2013); (v) made water supply affordable to poor and low-income households 
through  a  lifeline  tariff;  and  (vi)  increased  water  supply  and  sanitation  coverage  by  requiring 
households  to  improve  household  latrines  prior  to  receiving  free  household  water  connections.6 
By 2015, 12 more systems will be constructed and rehabilitated, and 10 PNPs will have corporate 
plans,  system-specific  service  agreements,  billing  and  accounting  systems,  and  asset 
depreciation accounts. ADB technical assistance is supporting the government’s strengthening of 
its regulations and facilitation of private sector participation in the water supply and sanitation.7  

7. 
Despite these impressive sector developments, NRW reduction needs to be prioritized, as 
high water losses in distribution networks adversely affect the efficiency and financial sustainability 
of water utilities and result in higher tariffs. In 2011, NRW for all 16 PNPs was estimated at 11.6 
million cubic meters per year (m3/year) or 28% of water production. These figures understate the 
actual  problem,  as  about  half  of  the  PNP  systems  provide  intermittent  supply.  NRW  would  be 
much higher if the systems are pressurized.8 If current NRW could be reduced to around 20%, an 
additional 3.3 million m3/year of piped water would be available to about 76,000 PNP customers, 
assuming  consumption  of  120  liters per  capita  per  day.  The  project  emphasizes  efficient  water 
use and helps participating PNPs reduce NRW in provincial water supply systems while providing 
capital investments for the provincial system and one small town system in the same province. 

Water  supply  and  sanitation  in  peri-urban  areas  is  a  neglected  area  of  service,  as 
8. 
expansion to these areas is often costly and technically challenging. In the Lao PDR, these areas 
are rapidly growing and becoming more densely populated, and they are home to about 60% of the

 urban population with low access to PNP piped water. The project provides investment to expand 
provincial capital town water supply systems to peri-urban areas at a lower incremental cost than 
installing a new system. It will optimize investment efficiency and expand the PNP customer base. 
It offers economies of scale, builds on established water supply systems, and enables tariff cross 
subsidy between the provincial and small town water supply systems. 

9. 
The project entails community-driven initiatives that complement the water and sanitation 
infrastructure components to ensure that benefits reach the poor and vulnerable in each village. In 
past  projects,  community  identification,  prioritization for  urban  environmental  improvements,  and 
community  awareness  were  instrumental  to  addressing  sanitation.  These  initiatives  mobilized 
additional government funds to extend improvements or develop complementary infrastructure.  

10. 
PNP  business  operations  can  be  strengthened  in  two  additional  areas:  customer 
relations and water safety plans. One-third of PNPs have a complaints register, and a few report 
complaints regularly to their board. The project encourages PNPs to improve their services and 
partnership with communities regarding water conservation and water loss reduction through a 
PNP  customer  relations  manager. 9 The  focus  on  NRW  management  will  ensure  that 
beneficiaries do not pay for PNP water losses. The free connection policy will minimize apparent 
losses (commercial) by reducing the incentive for illegal or unauthorized connections. 

11.  Monitoring  the  quality  of  piped  water,  in  accordance  with  the  Ministry  of  Health’s  draft 
drinking water quality standards, requires PNPs to prepare and implement water safety plans for 
all  systems.  Compliance  requires  sufficient  in-house  capacity  and  resources  to  test  all 
parameters.  The  project  supports  PNP  implementation  of  water  safety  plans  as  part  of  their 
regular corporate planning updates, improving drinking water quality monitoring through a staged 
approach  and  raising  awareness  about  compliance  with  standards.  The  application  of  water 
safety  plans  will  facilitate  discussions  on  water  security  issues  and  on  the  multiple  demands 
placed on raw water sources. Limited protection and competing demands for raw water sources 
causes  poor  water  quality,  water  shortage,  and  system  failure.  Rapid  urbanization,  agriculture, 
industry,  irrigation,  and  hydropower  development  pose  risks  of  possible  contamination  by 
wastewater,  pesticides,  and  fertilizer,  and  of  insufficient  water  flow  downstream.  The  project 
incorporates these factors into the preparation of each subproject.  

The  project  aligns  with  the  Lao  PDR’s  Seventh  National  Socio-Economic  Development 
12. 
Plan,  2011–2015,  which  envisions  graduation  from  least-developed  country  status  by  2020.  It 
contributes to the achievement of the Lao Millennium Development Goal targets for urban water 
supply and sanitation by 2015. ADB’s Lao PDR country partnership strategy, 2012–2016 and its 
Lao PDR urban development assessment strategy and road map both emphasize stronger rural–
urban  linkages  through  improved  urban  services  and  municipal  infrastructure.  The  project 
incorporates  lessons  from  ADB’s  independent  evaluations  and  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Water 
Operational Plan, 2011–2020 under Strategy 2020, which promotes working with corporate water 
inefficiencies,  and  stabilize  water 
utilities 
consumption  through robust  demand management.10 The  project  supports  the  Ministry  of  Public

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

13. 
The  impact  will  be  expanded  access  to  quality  and  reliable  piped  water  supply  and 
sanitation  services  for  the  urban  population  in  the  Lao  PDR.  The  outcome  will  be  improved 
performance of participating PNPs in delivering sustainable water supply and sanitation services. 
The  proposed  project  is  a  sector  lending  project  following  a  prioritized  list  of  subproject  towns 
based on the water supply investment plan. It provides capital to selected PNPs that are state 
(or  corporate)  companies,  have  prepared  a  corporate  plan,  and  have  arrears  at  less  than  90 
days. Each PNP will receive funds to expand and rehabilitate its provincial capital water supply 
system  and  to  construct  a  new  water  supply  system  in  a  small  town.  Each  town  selected  will 
have 4,000–20,000 residents. The project supports about six PNPs improve and develop water 
supply  systems  in  about  two  towns  per  province.  It  is  expected  to  improve  access  to  water 
supply for 155,000 people and improved sanitation for 160,000 people in these urban areas. 

C. 

Outputs 

14. 

The project will have the following five outputs. 

Output  1:  Improved  sector  coordination  and  policy  implementation.  This  will 
15. 
continue  reforms  introduced  under  previous  projects  and  implement  new  policy  reforms  to 
improve the performance of about six PNPs. This includes (i) strengthened sector coordination, 
including support to  help  coordinate the  subsector  working group  on  water  supply  and sanitation 
under  the  Technical  Working  Group  subgroup  on  urban  development,  subsector  biannual 
meetings, annual subsector performance review with development partners, and smaller subsector 
coordination  meetings;  (ii)  continued 
including  service 
agreements between PNPs and provincial governments, PNP training on corporate planning and 
financial  management,  tariff  adjustments,  free  connection  policy,  issuance  of  district  sanitation 
regulations,  and  the  use  of  simplified  corporate  plans;  and  (iii)  expanded  policy  implementation, 
including  nationalizing  a  free  connection  policy  and  sanitation  regulations;  wider  coordination  of 
NRW  management,  asset  management,  and  water  safety  plans;  and  the  establishment  of  a 
corporate planning helpdesk in the project coordination unit.  

implementation  of  policy  reforms, 

16. 
Output 2: Improved nonrevenue water management and water supply development. 
This  will  integrate  a  comprehensive  NRW  reduction  program  with  water  supply  development  in 
about  five  provincial  capitals.  The  NRW  program  applies  an  integrated  business  approach  that 
includes both investment for physical works and support for surveys, water audits and balances, 
record  drawings,  and  registers.  It  addresses  both  real  losses  (leakage)  and  apparent  losses 
(metering losses and water theft). Participating PNPs will be required to establish permanent leak 
detection  and  repair  teams  and  implement  disconnection  and  meter  management  policies. 
Experts  will  help  these  teams  implement  the  NRW  program.  PNPs  that  participate  in  the  NRW 
reduction program and the policy implementation activities under output 1 will be eligible to seek 

 

 financing for water supply rehabilitation and expansion of existing provincial systems to peri-urban 
areas. They will be eligible to receive O&M equipment and household connections and meters.11   

17. 
Output  3:  Developed  new  water  supply  systems  in  small  towns.  Safe,  affordable, 
reliable PNP piped water supply systems  will be built in the core urban areas of about six small 
district towns. PNPs that have agreed to participate in outputs 1 and 2 will be eligible for financing 
to  build  a  new  water  supply  system  in  a  small  district  in  the  same  province,  acquire  O&M 
equipment for it, and offer free connections and meters to households during construction.  

18. 
Output  4:  Enhanced  community  action  in  water  supply  and  sanitation.  This  will 
sustain the benefits from investments in small town water supply systems through complementary 
sanitation  and  awareness  activities.  The  output  includes  (i)  village  environmental  improvement 
(VEI) grants for core villages in a small town according to agreed eligibility criteria;12 (ii) improved 
household  sanitation  for  the  poor;13 (iii)  constructed  or  repaired  public  sanitation  facilities  where 
O&M  can  be  contracted  to  a  business  or  social  entity,  and  constructed  septage  disposal 
facilities  where  they  are  unavailable  in  the  subproject  area;  and  (iv)  increased  project  and 
hygiene awareness through stakeholder consultations and community participation, and water, 
sanitation,  and  hygiene  behaviour  change  in  areas  such  as  water  source  protection.  Activities 
will be coordinated by district authorities and implemented by village development committees. 

Output  5:  Strengthened  capacity  for  project  implementation,  operation,  and 
19. 
maintenance.  This  will  include  support  for  project  implementation  assistance  and  capacity 
development, including safeguards and O&M. Each participating PNP will benefit from on-the-job 
training  through  a  proposed  water  operators  partnership  with  a  regional  water  utility  such  as 
Thailand’s  Provincial  Waterworks  Authority. 14  The  output  supports  village  development 
committees  in  O&M  of  VEI  infrastructure  and  includes  incremental  administration  support  for 
project vehicles, project office equipment, and PNP operational and leak-detection equipment.

A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical  due  diligence  for  the  project  was  based  on  the  feasibility  studies  prepared  for 
25. 
three sample subproject towns: Pha Oudom, New Namtha, and Long. It assessed the suitability of 
technology used in water supply development, measures for energy efficiency and management, 
controls  for  NRW  management,  and  technical  viability  and  compatibility  with  local  conditions  for 
proposed  VEI.  The  project  adopts  appropriately  durable  and  sustainable  technologies  for  water 
and sanitation improvements. It considers measures to ensure energy efficiency using least-cost 
analyses.  The  current  designs  of  water  treatment  plants  suit  specific  site  conditions;  they  are 
robust and capable of handling a range of flows and raw water quality. They use gravity dosing of 
chemicals, hydraulic mixing of alum, horizontal sedimentation tanks, rapid gravity sand filters, and 
chlorination. The project includes initiatives to sustain low NRW, the free connections policy being 
disincentives  for  unauthorized  connections  and  water  theft.  Engineering  solutions  for  VEI 
infrastructure and equipment are selected for technical viability, compatibility with local conditions, 
and local O&M capacity. Household sanitation options will be selected for function, cost, long-term 
durability, and suitability for local social norms.  

B. 

Economic and Financial 

Economic and financial analyses of subproject water supply components accord with ADB 
26. 
guidelines. The project contributes significantly to improved economic well-being in small towns in 
terms of resource cost savings and consumer satisfaction. The estimated economic internal rates 
of return of the three sample subprojects range from 15.39% to 20.00%, higher than the assumed 
economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12.00%.  The  estimated  financial  internal  rates  of  return 
range from 6.20% to 8.55%, higher than the estimated weighted average cost of capital of 5.14%. 
The subprojects are most sensitive to implementation delays and decreased benefits or revenues, 
but  their  estimated  economic  and  financial  internal  rates  of  return  remain  above  the  economic 
opportunity cost of capital and the weighted average cost of capital under various scenarios. 

27. 
Each PNP participating in the project will implement utility-wide tariffs that are sufficient to 
fully  recover  utility-wide  O&M  costs;  recover  utility-wide  debt  service;  maintain  a  utility-wide  debt 
service ratio of at least 1.2 times once the project is operational; gradually recover an increasing 
proportion  of  annual  depreciation  expense  of  utility-wide  fixed  assets;  and  maintain  customer 
accounts receivable at less than 90 days of annual sales. The proposed utility-wide tariffs can meet 
the  sector’s  financial  objectives  of  cost  recovery  and  debt  service,  indicating  subproject  financial 
sustainability. Affordability analyses of the three sample subprojects show the proposed tariffs to be 
affordable to domestic consumers. PNPs will be required to review and adjust their tariffs annually.  

C. 

Governance 

28. 
Assessments  of  MPWT’s  financial  management  and  procurement  capacity  and  of  the 
project  coordination  unit  confirmed  that  project  implementation  arrangements,  which  follow 
previous ADB  water supply sector projects in the Lao PDR, are appropriate. The executing and 
implementing  agencies  have  experience  in  managing  externally  funded  projects  and  sufficient 
capacity to undertake international and national competitive bidding for civil works packages. The 
project’s focus on corporate planning and requirement for external audit of PNP financial accounts 
will improve governance. Output 5 will strengthen the capacity of project staff and provide on-the-
job  training.  The  project  coordination  unit  will  build  local  capacity  through  its  review  of 
procurement  and  disbursement  documents.  It  will  hire  a  national  accounting  firm  to  assist  with 
project accounts and build capacity. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 

 

 explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government  and  MPWT.  Specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the project administration manual (footnote 16).  

D. 

Poverty and Social 

29. 
The  project  will  have  a  direct  impact  on  the  health,  economic  prospects,  and  living 
conditions of town residents. It is gender category 2, effective gender mainstreaming. By 2021, the 
project will benefit about 160,000 residents in 113 core villages in 11 small towns, including 5,000 
poor  urban  households,  or  15%  of  all  households.  It  eliminates  barriers  to  access  for  the  urban 
poor  and  prioritizes  poor  districts  (output  3).  Health  benefits  will  be  derived  through  access  to 
improved  drinking  water; greater  water  availability for  sanitation  and  personal  hygiene;  increased 
access to improved sanitation and reduced open defecation; and improved septage management. 
Gender  benefits  for  women  will  result  from  greater  convenience,  reduced  physical  burden,  and 
time  savings  in  water  collection;  improved  family  health;  increased  privacy  and  dignity  when 
tending  to  sanitation  needs;  and  greater  hygiene  information  specific  to  women’s  health  and 
menstrual hygiene. The gender action plan furthers ADB’s experiences in gender mainstreaming 
in the urban water and sanitation sector in the Lao PDR.18 

E. 

Safeguards 

30. 
The  project  is  involuntary  resettlement  category  B,  as  it  will  not  entail  significant  land 
acquisition or resettlement. A resettlement framework and resettlement plans for the three sample 
subprojects  have  been  prepared.  The  resettlement  framework  will  guide  the  preparation  of  the 
remaining resettlement plans once subprojects are identified. 

The  project  is  indigenous  peoples  categories  B,  as  the  three  sample  subprojects  are  in 
31. 
urban areas, where ethnic groups are likely to be well integrated into society and so indigenous 
peoples plans are not required. An indigenous peoples planning framework has been prepared to 
guide  the  assessment  and  preparation  of  an  indigenous  peoples  plans,  if  necessary,  once  the 
remaining subprojects are identified during implementation. 

32. 
The  project  is  environment  category  B.  The  project  includes  a  sound  approach  to 
managing  water  security  issues.  Subprojects  are  not  expected  to  cause  any  irreversible 
environmental  impacts.  An  environmental  assessment  review  framework,  initial  environmental 
examinations for the project and three sample subprojects, and environment management plans 
have been prepared. Potential impacts of climate change and natural hazards to the project have 
been integrated into initial environmental examinations with recommendations for detailed design. 
Potential adverse impacts during construction are expected to be temporary and can be mitigated 
by executing the environment management plans required in the bidding and contract documents.  

33. 
Safeguard  documents  have  been  prepared  in  consultation  with  local  communities  and 
affected people accord with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), sector requirements, and 
government  regulations  and  disclosed  on  ADB  website.  A  grievance  redress  mechanism  will 
facilitate the resolution of complaints during project implementation. The project includes budget 
and  institutional  support  for  safeguard  document  preparation,  updates,  implementation,  and 
monitoring. It includes provision for an external resettlement monitor. A project information booklet 
for  resettlement  will  be  distributed  to  affected  people  during  the  detailed  measurement  survey. 
Safeguard documents have been approved by the government. Subproject plans will be updated 
after detailed design, cleared by the government and ADB prior to contract award, and disclosed 
on ADB’s website according to ADB’s information disclosure and consultation requirements.

3.7  Construct and commission new water supply systems (Q2 2016–Q3 2017). 
4.  Enhanced community action in urban water supply and sanitation 
4.1  Prepare stakeholder consultation and participation plan (Q4 2014–Q1 2015). 
4.2  Hold community planning and prioritization meetings (Q1 2015–Q2 2017). 
4.3  District authorities implement sanitation and hygiene activities (Q4 2015–Q1 2017). 
4.4  Include VEI and public latrines feasibility in respective subproject town feasibility 

studies and subproject appraisal reports (with activities 2.2 and 3.2). 

4.5  Identify VEI, poor households for latrine grants, and location of public latrines; prepare 

safeguard and O&M plans (Q4 2015). 

4.6  Bid, evaluate, and award contracts for VEI and public latrines (Q3–Q4 2016). 
4.7  Implement land acquisition and resettlement (Q1–Q2 2016). 
4.8  Implement VEI and construct public latrines (Q1–Q2 2017). 
5.  Strengthened capacity for project implementation and O&M 
5.1  Hold PCU and PIU project orientation (Q4 2014, Q1 2016, Q1 2017, Q2 2018). 
5.2  Finalize PPMS, disaggregating indicators by sex, income, and ethnicity (Q3 2014). 
5.3  Review and update capacity development plan (Q3 2014–onward). 
5.4  Review and update O&M plans in each corporate plan (with activities 2.7 and 3.4). 
5.5  Implement water safety plans within corporate plans (with activities 2.6 and 3.4). 
5.6  Provide continuous project implementation assistance (Q3 2014–onward). 
5.7  Manage and administer the project (Q3 2013–onward). 
5.8  Agree and commence on-the-job O&M training for each participating PNP (Q3–Q4 

2017, with activities 2.10 and 3.7).
